channel.title: Document: Deep South
channel.description:
A series of documentaries depicting the increasing importance of the South in the economic development of the United States. Narrated by Walt Whitaker, written and produced by Leroy Bannerman, with Dr. Walter B. Jones as senior consultant.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: From the ground up
item.description: Perhaps the plight of the farmer tells the story of the South best. Featuring analysis by Alexander Nunn, executive editor of The Progressive Farmer, in describing today's "agricultural revolution."
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Miner's lamp
item.description: Recordings made three-quarters of a mile below the surface relate a story of grime and sweat and courage -- the paradox where progress meant the downfall of the Southern coal industry.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Mississippi manuscript
item.description: The importance of waterways, including the Mississippi River. Colonel A.F. Clark, Jr., U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Memphis, analyzes the river's Jekyll-and-Hyde behavior.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Water resources development

item.title: Tall timber
item.description: Half the lumber used in the U.S. is annually produced down South. Forestry and what it means to the Southern economy; What they're doing to protect its future.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Portrait of strength
item.description: This program takes a look at the steel industry in the South.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: U.S. History (1900-present)

item.title: Goodly land
item.description: When Hernando DeSoto referred to the South as the "goodly land", he had not the slightest idea of the wealth below its scenic wonder. Today's new industrial Dixie is the source of many minerals-- among these, rutile, the ore for making titanium.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Pipeline to progress
item.description: Pipelines trace the far-reaching effects of petroleum in a modern South. A tour through the huge Esso refinery in Baton Rouge, La.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Men of magic
item.description: Chemical industries account for much of the New South development. Dr. Frank Soday, director of research for Chemstrand Corporation of Decatur, Alabama and William E. Crooks, head of Celanese Corporation of Rome, Georgia are featured.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Textile fabrics--United States

item.title: The symphony of Southern power
item.description: Which comes first-- industry or power? A pioneer in power development in Dixie, Thomas W. Martin, reveals the vital role of power companies in the South.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Social conditions

item.title: Black gold: A study in oil
item.description: The never-ending search for oil, recorded deep in Louisiana marsh country. Rowdy roughnecks tell their own story.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Domes of destiny
item.description: Considerable wealth and well-being are derived from natural phenomena called "sale domes." Beneath the hump-like hill is a core of solid salt--often sulphur and oil. For this reason, it is a favorite location for chemical industries along the Gulf Coast
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Sulfur industry--United States

item.title: Fruit of thy labor
item.description: Growth and impact of the multi-million dollar citrus business on the South. Dr. Walter Jones interviews Dr. L. G. MacDowell, the researcher who helped perfect frozen juice concentrate.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Sunrise down south
item.description: This program presents an overview of the growth in various industries in the American South.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Look away, Dixieland
item.description: New Orleans Port Director Louis Bourgeois emphasizes the importance of world trade for national economy and world peace. A survey of Southern ports, including Hampton Roads and New Orleans.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Building a better Southland
item.description: Increased construction activity below the Mason-Dixon Line heralds a recent sign of a prospering South. But this building boom also means an increased demand for building necessities, such as brick and cement, which Southerners are providing themselves.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: The challenge of a changing South
item.description: From plantation days to the depths of economic despair, back again to the brink of unequaled promise is the pendulum swing of Southern life. This review poses the challenge of the past and present.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Magnolias and the manufacturer
item.description: Does everyone welcome a changing South? Ironically, many Southerners resent the movement toward industrailzation, fearing it will destroy tradition. Actually, both are united in the tourist trade.
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Southern States--Economic conditions

item.title: Textile tapestry
item.description: Textiles date back to the days when cotton was king, but today forms a cloth of a different design. Modern developments, better working conditions, improved products are but a few threads of progress. Is cotton now obsolete due to man-made fibers?
item.dc:creator: Bannerman, R. Leroy
item.dc:subject: Textile industry--Southern States
